Abstract

Standard game theory assumes that the structure of the game is common knowledge among players. We relax this assumption by considering extensive games where agents may be unaware of the complete structure of the game. In particular, they may not be aware of moves that they and other agents can make. We show how such games can be represented; the key idea is to describe the game from the point of view of every agent at every node of the game tree. We provide a generalization of Nash equilibrium and show that every game with awareness has a generalized Nash equilibrium. Finally, we extend these results to games with awareness of unawareness, where a player iùëñi may be aware that a player jùëój can make moves that iùëñi is not aware of, and to subjective games, where payers may have no common knowledge regarding the actual game and their beliefs are incompatible with a common prior.

keywords: Economic Theory, Foundations of Game Theory, Awareness, Solution Concepts.

1 Introduction

Standard game theory models implicitly assume that all significant aspects of the game (payoffs, moves available, etc.) are common knowledge among the players. While such common knowledge may seem unreasonable, there are well-known techniques going back to Harsanyi [?] for transforming a game where some aspects are not common knowledge to one where they are common knowledge. All these techniques assume that players are at least aware of all possible moves in the game. However, this is not always a reasonable assumption. For example, sleazy companies assume that consumers are not aware that they can lodge complaints if there are problems; in a war setting, having technology that an enemy is unaware of (and thus being able to make moves that the enemy is unaware of) can be critical; in financial markets, some investors may not be aware of certain investment strategies (complicated hedging strategies, for example, or tax-avoidance strategies).

In a standard game, a set of strategies is a Nash equilibrium if each agent‚Äôs strategy is a best response to the other agents‚Äô strategies, so each agent iùëñi would continue playing its strategy even if iùëñi knew what strategies the other agents were using. To understand the relevance of adding the possibility of unawareness to the analysis of games, consider the game shown in Figure¬†1. One Nash equilibrium of this game has Aùê¥A playing acrossA and BùêµB playing downB. However, suppose that Aùê¥A is not aware that BùêµB can play downB. In that case, if Aùê¥A is rational, Aùê¥A will play downA. Therefore, Nash equilibrium does not seem to be the appropriate solution concept here. Although Aùê¥A would play acrossA if Aùê¥A knew that BùêµB were going to play downB, Aùê¥A cannot even contemplate this possibility, let alone know it.

Our goal is to find appropriate solution concepts for extensive games with possibly unaware players, and more generally, to find ways of representing multiagent systems where some agents may not be aware of features of the system. To do this, we must first find an appropriate representation for such games. The first step in doing so is to explicitly represent what players are aware of at each node. We do this by using what we call an augmented game. An augmented game describes how awareness changes over time. For example, perhaps Aùê¥A playing acrossA will result in BùêµB becoming aware of the possibility of playing downB. In financial settings, one effect of players using certain investment strategies is that other players become aware of the possibility of using that strategy. Strategic thinking in such games must involve taking this possibility into account.

We cannot in general represent what is going on using only one augmented game. The standard representation of a game implicitly assumes that (it is common knowledge that) the modeler and the players all understand the game the same way. This is no longer true once we allow for the possibility of unawareness, since a player‚Äôs description of the game can now involve only those aspects of the game that he is aware of. Thus, the full description of the game with awareness is given by a set of augmented games, one for the modeler and one for each game that at least one of the agents thinks might be the true game in some situation.

Continuing with the game in Figure¬†1, the augmented game from the point of view of the type of BùêµB that is unaware of the possibility of playing downB would just include Aùê¥A‚Äôs moves downA and acrossA and the move acrossB. In that augmented game, player Aùê¥A is also unaware of the move downB. By way of contrast, the augmented game from the point of view of the type of BùêµB that is aware of downB would include the move downB, but may also allow for the possibility that Aùê¥A is not aware that BùêµB is aware of this move.

The standard notion of Nash equilibrium consists of a collection of strategies, one for each player. Our generalization consists of a collection of strategies, one for each pair (i,Œì‚Ä≤)ùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤(i,\Gamma^{\prime}), where Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime} is a game that agent iùëñi considers to be the true game in some situation. Intuitively, the strategy for a player iùëñi at Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime} is the strategy iùëñi would play in situations where iùëñi believes that the true game is Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime}. To understand why we may need to consider different strategies consider, for example, the game of Figure¬†1. BùêµB would play differently depending on whether or not he was aware of downB. Roughly speaking, a set of strategies, one for each pair (i,Œì‚Ä≤)ùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤(i,\Gamma^{\prime}), is a generalized Nash equilibrium if the strategy for (i,Œì‚Ä≤)ùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤(i,\Gamma^{\prime}) is a best response for player iùëñi if the true game is Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime}, given the strategies being used by the other players in Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime}.

We argue that this notion of equilibrium correctly captures our intuitions. We then show that every game with awareness has a generalized Nash equilibrium by associating with a game with awareness a standard game (where agents are aware of all moves) such that there is a one-to-one correspondence between generalized Nash equilibria of the game with awareness and Nash equilibria of the standard game.

For ease of exposition, for most of the paper we focus on games where agents are not aware of their lack of awareness. That is, we do not consider games where one player might be aware that there are moves that another player (or even she herself) might be able to make, although she is not aware of what they are. Such awareness of unawareness can be quite relevant in practice. For example, in the war setting described above, even if one side cannot conceive of a new technology available to the enemy, they might believe that there is some move available to the enemy without understanding what that particular move is. This, in turn, may encourage peace overtures. To take another example, an agent might delay making a decision because she considers it possible that she might learn about more possible moves, even if she is not aware of what these moves are.

If we interpret ‚Äúlack of awareness‚Äù as ‚Äúunable to compute‚Äù (cf.¬†[2]), then awareness of unawareness becomes even more significant. Consider a chess game. Although all players understand in principle all the moves that can be made, they are certainly not aware of all consequences of all moves. A more accurate representation of chess would model this computational unawareness explicitly. We provide such a representation.

Roughly speaking, we capture the fact that player iùëñi is aware that, at a node h‚Ñéh in the game tree, there is a move that jùëój can make she (iùëñi) is not aware by having iùëñi‚Äôs subjective representation of the game include a ‚Äúvirtual‚Äù move for jùëój at node h‚Ñéh. Since iùëñi might have only an incomplete understanding of what can happen after this move,

iùëñi simply describes what she believes will be the game after the virtual move, to the extent that she can. For example, if she has no idea what will happen after the virtual move, then she can describe her beliefs regarding the payoffs of the game. Thus, our representation can be viewed as a generalization of how chess programs analyze chess games. They explore the game tree up to a certain point, and then evaluate the board position at that point. We can think of the payoffs following a virtual move by jùëój in iùëñi‚Äôs subjective representation of a chess game as describing the evaluation of the board from iùëñi‚Äôs point of view. This seems like a much more reasonable representation of the game than the standard complete game tree!

Our framework is flexible enough to deal with games where there is lack of common knowledge about what is the game being played. In particular, we can deal with lack of common knowledge regarding the utilities, who moves next, the structure of other players‚Äô information sets, and the probability of nature‚Äôs moves (even in cases where there is no common prior compatible with the players‚Äô beliefs regarding nature).

Recently, Feinberg¬†[?, ?] also studied games with awareness. Feinberg¬†[?] gives a definition of extended Nash equilibrium in normal-form games. Although his definition stems from much the same intuitions as ours (although some details are different‚Äîsee Section¬†6), it is expressed syntactically. Each player is characterized by a complete description of what moves and players he is aware of, what moves and players he is aware that each other player is aware of, and so on through all levels of iterated awareness. Feinberg¬†[?] deals with extensive-form games and defines solution concepts only indirectly, via a syntactic epistemic characterization. His approach lacks a more direct semantic framework, which our model provides. He also does not deal with awareness of unawareness.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In Section¬†2, we describe how we represent different awareness levels in a game. In Section¬†3, we use our representation to define a generalized notion of Nash equilibrium, and we prove its existence in games with awareness. In Section¬†4, we describe how we can extend our approach to deal with awareness of unawareness. In Section¬†5, we describe how to extend our framework to deal with games where there is lack of common knowledge, even if awareness is not an issue. We compare our work to others in the literature, particularly Feinberg‚Äôs, in Section¬†6, and conclude in Section¬†7.

2 Modeling awareness

The first step in dealing with awareness is modeling it. To this end, we consider augmented games. We start with a standard game, described by a game tree ŒìŒì\Gamma (as in Figure¬†1). An augmented game Œì+superscriptŒì\Gamma^{+} based on ŒìŒì\Gamma essentially augments ŒìŒì\Gamma by describing each agent‚Äôs awareness level at each node, where player iùëñi‚Äôs awareness level at a node h‚Ñéh is essentially the set of runs (complete histories) in ŒìŒì\Gamma that iùëñi is aware of at node h‚Ñéh. A player‚Äôs awareness level may change over time, as the player becomes aware of more moves.

Our formal definition of augmented game is based on the definition of extensive game given by Osborne and Rubinstein [?]. We start by briefly reviewing Osborne and Rubinstein‚Äôs definition.

An augmented game is defined much like an extensive game; the only essential difference is that at each nonterminal history we not only determine the player moving but also her awareness level. This is a perfect recall requirement; players do not forget histories that they were aware of.

    If h‚Ñéh and h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime} are in the same information set in Œì+superscriptŒì\Gamma^{+}, then h¬Ø¬Ø‚Ñé\overline{h} and h¬Ø‚Ä≤superscript¬Ø‚Ñé‚Ä≤\overline{h}^{\prime} are in the same information set in¬†ŒìŒì\Gamma.

  • A9.

    If h‚Ñéh and h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime} are histories in both Œì+superscriptŒì\Gamma^{+} and ŒìŒì\Gamma, and h¬Ø¬Ø‚Ñé\overline{h} and h¬Ø‚Ä≤superscript¬Ø‚Ñé‚Ä≤\overline{h}^{\prime} are in the same information set in ŒìŒì\Gamma, then h‚Ñéh and h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime} are in the same information set in Œì+superscriptŒì\Gamma^{+}.

  • A10.

    For all i‚ààN+ùëñsuperscriptùëÅi\in N^{+} and h‚ààHi+‚Ñésuperscriptsubscriptùêªùëñh\in H_{i}^{+}, if h‚Ä≤,h‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚ààAi‚Äã(h)superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤‚Ä≤subscriptùê¥ùëñ‚Ñéh^{\prime},h^{\prime\prime}\in{A}_{i}(h), h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime} and h‚Ä≤‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤‚Ä≤h^{\prime\prime} are in the same information set in ŒìŒì\Gamma, then h‚Ä≤‚ãÖ‚ü®m‚ü©‚ààAi‚Äã(h)‚ãÖsuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤delimited-‚ü®‚ü©ùëösubscriptùê¥ùëñ‚Ñéh^{\prime}\cdot\langle m\rangle\in{A}_{i}(h) iff h‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚ãÖ‚ü®m‚ü©‚ààAi‚Äã(h)‚ãÖsuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤‚Ä≤delimited-‚ü®‚ü©ùëösubscriptùê¥ùëñ‚Ñéh^{\prime\prime}\cdot\langle m\rangle\in{A}_{i}(h).

  • A11.

    {z¬Ø:z‚ààZ+}‚äÜZconditional-set¬Øùëßùëßsuperscriptùëçùëç\{\overline{z}:z\in Z^{+}\}\subseteq Z; moreover, for all i‚ààN+ùëñsuperscriptùëÅi\in N^{+}, h‚ààHi+‚Ñésubscriptsuperscriptùêªùëñh\in H^{+}_{i}, if zùëßz is a terminal history in Ai+‚Äã(h)superscriptsubscriptùê¥ùëñ‚Ñé{A}_{i}^{+}(h) (i.e., if z‚ààAi+‚Äã(h)ùëßsuperscriptsubscriptùê¥ùëñ‚Ñéz\in A_{i}^{+}(h) and zùëßz is not a strict prefix of another element of Ai+‚Äã(h)superscriptsubscriptùê¥ùëñ‚ÑéA_{i}^{+}(h)), then z‚äÜZùëßùëçz\subseteq Z.   • A12.

We have included the clause ‚Äúif z¬Ø‚ààZ¬Øùëßùëç\overline{z}\in Z‚Äù so that A12 is applicable when we consider awareness of unawareness, where we drop A11.)

Conditions A1‚ÄìA12 are intended to capture our intuitions regarding information sets, awareness, and common knowledge. To allow us to focus on issues directly related to awareness, we have implicitly assumed that there is common knowledge of (1) who moves at histories in the underlying game (this is captured by the fact that P+‚Äã(h)=P‚Äã(h¬Ø)superscriptùëÉ‚ÑéùëÉ¬Ø‚ÑéP^{+}(h)=P(\overline{h}) unless P+‚Äã(h)=csuperscriptùëÉ‚ÑéùëêP^{+}(h)=c and Mh+‚à©M=‚àÖsubscriptsuperscriptùëÄ‚ÑéùëÄM^{+}_{h}\cap M=\emptyset ‚Äîeither the same player or nature moves at both h‚Ñéh and h¬Ø¬Ø‚Ñé\overline{h} unless nature makes an ‚Äúawareness‚Äù move at h‚Ñéh), (2) what the payoffs are in the underlying game (since u+‚Äã(z¬Ø)=u‚Äã(z)superscriptùë¢¬Øùëßùë¢ùëßu^{+}(\overline{z})=u(z)), and (3) what the information sets are in the underlying game (see A8‚ÄìA10). Our approach is flexible enough to allow us to drop these assumptions; see Section¬†5.

To understand A8‚ÄìA10, we must first discuss our view of information sets. As pointed out by Halpern¬†[?], special attention must be given to the interpretation of information sets in game trees. This issue requires even more care in games with awareness. The standard intuition for information sets is that a player considers all the histories in his information set possible. But this intuition does not apply in augmented games. In an augmented game, there may be some histories in an iùëñi-information set that iùëñi is not aware of; player iùëñi cannot consider these histories possible. For example, consider finitely repeated prisoners dilemma where Alice and Bob each move twice before their moves are revealed. Even if Bob is not aware of defection, his information set after Alice‚Äôs first move in the modeler‚Äôs game will still contain the history where Alice defects.

We interpret an iùëñi-information set to be the set of all histories where player iùëñi has the same local state. Intuitively, this local states encodes all the information that iùëñi has about the moves he can make, what moves have been made, the other players in the game, his strategy, and so on. We assume that player iùëñi‚Äôs local state is characterized by the sequence of signals that that iùëñi has received in the course of the game. Therefore, h‚Ñéh and h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime} are in the same iùëñi-information set in ŒìŒì\Gamma iff iùëñi received the same sequence of signals in both histories.

In standard extensive games, the sequence of signals a player receives after every history h‚Ñéh is assumed to be common knowledge. (This assumption is implicit in the assumption that the game, is common knowledge, and hence so are the information sets.) As we said, we continue to assume this in games with awareness (although we show how the assumption can be dropped in Section¬†5). That is why we require in A8 that if h‚Ñéh and h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime} are in the same iùëñi-information in an augmented game, then h¬Ø¬Ø‚Ñé\overline{h} and h¬Ø‚Ä≤superscript¬Ø‚Ñé‚Ä≤\overline{h}^{\prime} must be in the same iùëñi-information set in the underlying game. The converse of A8 does not necessarily hold. It could well be the case that h¬Ø¬Ø‚Ñé\overline{h} and h¬Ø‚Ä≤superscript¬Ø‚Ñé‚Ä≤\overline{h}^{\prime} are in the same iùëñi-information set, but since iùëñi receives different signals from nature, h‚Ñéh and h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime} are not in the same information set. On the other hand, if all the moves in h‚Ñéh and h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime} are already in the underlying game, then if h‚Ñéh and h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime} are in the same information set of ŒìŒì\Gamma, they should be in the same information set of Œì+superscriptŒì\Gamma^{+}. This is the content of A9. Since, the signals received by a player determine the moves he has available, if player iùëñi is aware of two histories in the same information set in ŒìŒì\Gamma, he must be aware of the same set of moves available at both of these histories. A10 captures that intuition.

For the remainder of the paper, we use the following notation: for a (standard or augmented) game ŒìssuperscriptŒìùë†\Gamma^{s}, we denote the components of ŒìssuperscriptŒìùë†\Gamma^{s} with the same superscript sùë†s, so that we have MssuperscriptùëÄùë†M^{s}, Hssuperscriptùêªùë†H^{s}, and so on. Thus, from here on we do not explicitly describe the components of a game.

An augmented game describes either the modeler‚Äôs view of the game or the subjective view of the game of one of the players, and includes both moves of the underlying game and moves of nature that change awareness. For example, consider again the game shown in Figure¬†1 and suppose that

  • ‚Ä¢

    players Aùê¥A and BùêµB are aware of all histories of the game;

  • ‚Ä¢

    player Aùê¥A is uncertain as to whether player BùêµB is aware of run ‚ü®‚ü®\langleacrossA,‚Äâdown‚ü©B{}_{B}\rangle and believes that he is unaware of it with probability pùëùp; and

  • ‚Ä¢

    the type of player BùêµB that is aware of the run ‚ü®‚ü®\langleacrossA, down‚ü©B{}_{B}\rangle is aware that player Aùê¥A is aware of all histories, and he knows Aùê¥A is uncertain about his awareness level and knows the probability pùëùp.

Because Aùê¥A and BùêµB are actually aware of all histories of the underlying game, from the point of view of the modeler, the augmented game is essentially identical to the game described in Figure¬†1, with the awareness level of both players Aùê¥A and BùêµB consisting of all histories of the underlying game. However, when Aùê¥A moves at the node labeled Aùê¥A in the modeler‚Äôs game, she believes that the actual augmented game is ŒìAsuperscriptŒìùê¥\Gamma^{A}, as described in Figure¬†2. In ŒìAsuperscriptŒìùê¥\Gamma^{A}, nature‚Äôs initial move captures Aùê¥A‚Äôs uncertainty about BùêµB‚Äôs awareness level. At the information set labeled A‚Äã.1ùê¥.1A.1, Aùê¥A is aware of all the runs of the underlying game. Moreover, at this information set, Aùê¥A believes that the true game is ŒìAsuperscriptŒìùê¥\Gamma^{A}.

At the node labeled B‚Äã.1ùêµ.1B.1, BùêµB is aware of all the runs of the underlying game and believes that the true game is the modeler‚Äôs game; but at the node labeled B‚Äã.2ùêµ.2B.2, BùêµB is not aware that he can play downB, and so believes that the true game is the augmented game ŒìBsuperscriptŒìùêµ\Gamma^{B} described in Figure¬†3. At the nodes labeled A‚Äã.3ùê¥.3A.3 and B‚Äã.3ùêµ.3B.3 in the game ŒìBsuperscriptŒìùêµ\Gamma^{B}, neither Aùê¥A nor BùêµB is aware of the move downB. Moreover, both players think the true game is ŒìBsuperscriptŒìùêµ\Gamma^{B}.

As this example should make clear, to model a game with possibly unaware players, we need to consider not just one augmented game, but a collection of them. Moreover, we need to describe, at each history in an augmented game, which augmented game the player playing at that history believes is the actual augmented game being played.

To capture these intuitions, we define a game with awareness based on Œì=(N,M,H,P,fc,{‚Ñêi:i‚ààN},{ui:i‚ààN})ŒìùëÅùëÄùêªùëÉsubscriptùëìùëêconditional-setsubscript‚ÑêùëñùëñùëÅconditional-setsubscriptùë¢ùëñùëñùëÅ\Gamma=(N,M,H,P,f_{c},\{{\cal I}_{i}:i\in N\},\{u_{i}:i\in N\}) to be a tuple Œì‚àó=(ùí¢,Œìm,‚Ñ±)superscriptŒìùí¢superscriptŒìùëö‚Ñ±\Gamma^{*}=({\cal G},\Gamma^{m},{\cal F}), where

  • ‚Ä¢

    ùí¢ùí¢{\cal G} is a countable set of augmented games based on ŒìŒì\Gamma, of which one is ŒìmsuperscriptŒìùëö\Gamma^{m};

    ‚Ñ±‚Ñ±{\cal F} maps an augmented game Œì+‚ààùí¢superscriptŒìùí¢\Gamma^{+}\in{\cal G} and a history h‚Ñéh in Œì+superscriptŒì\Gamma^{+} such that P+‚Äã(h)=isuperscriptùëÉ‚ÑéùëñP^{+}(h)=i to a pair (Œìh,I)superscriptŒì‚Ñéùêº(\Gamma^{h},I), where Œìh‚ààùí¢superscriptŒì‚Ñéùí¢\Gamma^{h}\in{\cal G} and IùêºI is an iùëñi-information set in game ŒìhsuperscriptŒì‚Ñé\Gamma^{h}.

Intuitively, ŒìmsuperscriptŒìùëö\Gamma^{m} is the game from the point of view of an omniscient modeler. If player iùëñi moves at h‚Ñéh in game Œì+‚ààùí¢superscriptŒìùí¢\Gamma^{+}\in{\cal G} and ‚Ñ±‚Äã(Œì+,h)=(Œìh,I)‚Ñ±superscriptŒì‚ÑésuperscriptŒì‚Ñéùêº{\cal F}(\Gamma^{+},h)=(\Gamma^{h},I), then ŒìhsuperscriptŒì‚Ñé\Gamma^{h} is the game that iùëñi believes to be the true game when the history is h‚Ñéh, and IùêºI consists of the set of histories in ŒìhsuperscriptŒì‚Ñé\Gamma^{h} he currently considers possible. For example, in the examples described in Figures¬†2 and¬†3, taking ŒìmsuperscriptŒìùëö\Gamma^{m} to be the augmented game in Figure¬†1, we have ‚Ñ±‚Äã(Œìm,‚ü®‚ü©)=(ŒìA,I)‚Ñ±superscriptŒìùëösuperscriptŒìùê¥ùêº{\cal F}(\Gamma^{m},\langle\,\rangle)=(\Gamma^{A},I), where IùêºI is the information set labeled A‚Äã.1ùê¥.1A.1 in Figure¬†2, and ‚Ñ±(ŒìA,‚ü®{\cal F}(\Gamma^{A},\langleunaware,across‚ü©A)=(ŒìB,{‚ü®{}_{A}\rangle)=(\Gamma^{B},\{\langleacross‚ü©A}){}_{A}\rangle\}).

It may seem that by making ‚Ñ±‚Ñ±{\cal F} a function we cannot capture a player‚Äôs uncertainty about the game being played. However, we can capture such uncertainty by folding it into nature‚Äôs move. For example, we capture Aùê¥A‚Äôs uncertainty about whether BùêµB is aware of being able to move downB in the augmented game ŒìAsuperscriptŒìùê¥\Gamma^{A} illustrated in Figure¬†2 by having nature decide this at the first step. It should be clear that this gives a general approach to capturing such uncertainty.

The augmented game ŒìmsuperscriptŒìùëö\Gamma^{m} and the mapping ‚Ñ±‚Ñ±{\cal F} must satisfy a number of consistency conditions. The first set of conditions applies to ŒìmsuperscriptŒìùëö\Gamma^{m}. Since the modeler is presumed to be omniscient, the conditions say that the modeler is aware of all the players and moves of the underlying game.

  • M1.

    Nm=NsuperscriptùëÅùëöùëÅN^{m}=N.

  • M2.

    M‚äÜMmùëÄsuperscriptùëÄùëöM\subseteq M^{m} and {z¬Ø:z‚ààZm}=Zconditional-set¬Øùëßùëßsuperscriptùëçùëöùëç\{\overline{z}:z\in Z^{m}\}=Z.

  • M3.

    If Pm‚Äã(h)‚ààNsuperscriptùëÉùëö‚ÑéùëÅP^{m}(h)\in N, then Mhm=Mh¬ØsubscriptsuperscriptùëÄùëö‚ÑésubscriptùëÄ¬Ø‚ÑéM^{m}_{h}=M_{\overline{h}}. If Pm‚Äã(h)=csuperscriptùëÉùëö‚ÑéùëêP^{m}(h)=c, then either Mhm‚à©M=‚àÖsubscriptsuperscriptùëÄùëö‚ÑéùëÄM^{m}_{h}\cap M=\emptyset or Mhm=Mh¬ØsubscriptsuperscriptùëÄùëö‚ÑésubscriptùëÄ¬Ø‚ÑéM^{m}_{h}=M_{\overline{h}} and fcm(‚ãÖ‚à£h)=fc(‚ãÖ‚à£h¬Ø)\mbox{$f^{m}_{c}(\cdot\mid h)$}=f_{c}(\cdot\mid\overline{h}).

M1, M2 and M3 enforce the intuition that the modeler understands the underlying game. He knows all the players and possible moves, and understands how nature‚Äôs moves work in the underlying game ŒìŒì\Gamma. It may seem somewhat surprising that there is no analogue of the second part of M3 (i.e., the constraint of fcmsuperscriptsubscriptùëìùëêùëöf_{c}^{m}) for all augmented games. While it makes sense to have such an analogue if nature‚Äôs moves are in some sense objective, it seems like an unreasonable requirement that all player‚Äôs should agree on these probabilities in general. This is especially so in the case that a player suddenly becomes aware of some moves of nature that he was not aware of before. It does not seem reasonable to assume that this awareness should come along with an understanding of the probabilities of these moves. Of course, we could require such an analogue of M3. Since the set of games that have such a requirement is a subset of the games we consider, all our results apply without change if such a requirement is imposed.

Although the modeler understands the underlying game ŒìŒì\Gamma, ŒìmsuperscriptŒìùëö\Gamma^{m} is not uniquely determined by ŒìŒì\Gamma. There may be many modeler‚Äôs games based on ŒìŒì\Gamma, where the players have different awareness levels and the awareness changes in different ways.

The game ŒìmsuperscriptŒìùëö\Gamma^{m} can be thought of as a description of ‚Äúreality‚Äù; it describes the effect of moves in the underlying game and how players‚Äô awareness levels change. The other games in ùí¢ùí¢{\cal G} describe a player‚Äôs subjective view of the situation. The constraints on the mapping ‚Ñ±‚Ñ±{\cal F} that we now describe capture desirable properties of awareness.

    There exists a history h‚Ä≤‚ààIsuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤ùêºh^{\prime}\in I such that for every prefix h‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚ãÖ‚ü®m‚ü©‚ãÖsuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤‚Ä≤delimited-‚ü®‚ü©ùëöh^{\prime\prime}\cdot\langle m\rangle of h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime}, if Ph‚Äã(h‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)=j‚ààNhsuperscriptùëÉ‚Ñésuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ùëósuperscriptùëÅ‚ÑéP^{h}(h^{\prime\prime})=j\in N^{h} and ‚Ñ±‚Äã(Œìh,h‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)=(Œì‚Ä≤,I‚Ä≤)‚Ñ±superscriptŒì‚Ñésuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤superscriptùêº‚Ä≤{\cal F}(\Gamma^{h},h^{\prime\prime})=(\Gamma^{\prime},I^{\prime}), then for all h1‚ààI‚Ä≤subscript‚Ñé1superscriptùêº‚Ä≤h_{1}\in I^{\prime}, h1‚ãÖ‚ü®m‚ü©‚ààH‚Ä≤‚ãÖsubscript‚Ñé1delimited-‚ü®‚ü©ùëösuperscriptùêª‚Ä≤h_{1}\cdot\langle m\rangle\in H^{\prime}.

  • C10.

    If h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime} and h‚Ä≤‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤‚Ä≤h^{\prime\prime} are histories in both Œì+superscriptŒì\Gamma^{+} and ŒìhsuperscriptŒì‚Ñé\Gamma^{h}, then h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime} and h‚Ä≤‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤‚Ä≤h^{\prime\prime} are in the same iùëñi-information set in Œì+superscriptŒì\Gamma^{+} iff h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime} and h‚Ä≤‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤‚Ä≤h^{\prime\prime} are in the same iùëñi-information set in ŒìhsuperscriptŒì‚Ñé\Gamma^{h}.

Suppose that ‚Ñ±‚Äã(Œì+,h)=(Œìh,I)‚Ñ±superscriptŒì‚ÑésuperscriptŒì‚Ñéùêº{\cal F}(\Gamma^{+},h)=(\Gamma^{h},I). C1 guarantees that the set of histories of the underlying game player iùëñi is aware of is exactly the set of histories of the underlying game that appear in ŒìhsuperscriptŒì‚Ñé\Gamma^{h}. C2 states that no player in ŒìhsuperscriptŒì‚Ñé\Gamma^{h} can be aware of histories not in aùëéa. The second part of C2 implies that the set of moves available to player jùëój at h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime} is just the set of moves that player iùëñi is aware of that are available to jùëój at h¬Ø‚Ä≤superscript¬Ø‚Ñé‚Ä≤\overline{h}^{\prime} in the underlying game. C3 guarantees that for all histories h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime} indistinguishable from h‚Ñéh that player iùëñi is aware of, there exists some history h‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚ààIsuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ùêºh^{\prime\prime}\in I differing from h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime} at most in some moves of nature that change awareness levels. C4 says that at all histories in IùêºI player iùëñi indeed thinks the game is ŒìhsuperscriptŒì‚Ñé\Gamma^{h} and that the information set is IùêºI. C5 says that player iùëñi‚Äôs subjective view of the game changes only if iùëñi becomes aware of more moves and is the same at histories in H+superscriptùêªH^{+} that iùëñi cannot distinguish. C6 captures the assumption that at all histories iùëñi considers possible, he must have gotten the same signals as he does in the actual history.

C7 says that if while moving at history h‚Ñéh player iùëñi thinks that Œì+superscriptŒì\Gamma^{+} is the actual game, then he considers possible all and only histories in the information set containing h‚Ñéh. C8 is a consequence of the perfect recall assumption. C8 says that if, at history h‚Ñéh, iùëñi considers h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime} possible, then for every prefix h1‚Ä≤superscriptsubscript‚Ñé1‚Ä≤h_{1}^{\prime} of h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime} there is a corresponding prefix of h‚Ñéh where iùëñi considers himself to be playing the same game, and similarly, for every prefix of h‚Ñéh there is a prefix of h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime} where iùëñi considers himself to be playing the same game. Moreover, iùëñi makes the same move at these prefixes.

The intuition behind condition C9 is that player iùëñi knows that player jùëój only make moves that jùëój is aware of. Therefore, player iùëñi must consider at least one history h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime} where he believes that every player jùëój made a move that jùëój was aware of. It follows from A11, C1, C2, and C9 that there is a run going through IùêºI where every player jùëój makes a move that player iùëñi believes that jùëój is aware of.

Since we assume that players have (modulo awareness) common knowledge about information sets, if Œì+superscriptŒì\Gamma^{+} is the game from the point of view of player jùëój (or the modeler) and there are histories h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime} and h‚Ä≤‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤‚Ä≤h^{\prime\prime} in both Œì+superscriptŒì\Gamma^{+} and ŒìhsuperscriptŒì‚Ñé\Gamma^{h}, then player jùëój (or the modeler) knows that player iùëñi gets the same signals in both h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime} and h‚Ä≤‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤‚Ä≤h^{\prime\prime} iff he knows that player iùëñi knows that he gets the same signals in those histories. C10 captures that intuition.

Just as ŒìmsuperscriptŒìùëö\Gamma^{m} is not uniquely determined by ŒìŒì\Gamma, ‚Ñ±‚Äã(Œì+,h)‚Ñ±superscriptŒì‚Ñé{\cal F}(\Gamma^{+},h) depends on more than just the awareness level of the player who moves at h‚Ñéh. That is, even if Ai‚Äã(h)=Ai‚Äã(h‚Ä≤)subscriptùê¥ùëñ‚Ñésubscriptùê¥ùëñsuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤{A}_{i}(h)={A}_{i}(h^{\prime}), we may have ‚Ñ±‚Äã(Œì+,h)=(Œìh,I)‚Ñ±superscriptŒì‚ÑésuperscriptŒì‚Ñéùêº{\cal F}(\Gamma^{+},h)=(\Gamma^{h},I) and ‚Ñ±‚Äã(Œì+,h‚Ä≤)=(Œìh‚Ä≤,I‚Ä≤)‚Ñ±superscriptŒìsuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤superscriptŒìsuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤superscriptùêº‚Ä≤{\cal F}(\Gamma^{+},h^{\prime})=(\Gamma^{h^{\prime}},I^{\prime}) with Œìh‚â†Œìh‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚ÑésuperscriptŒìsuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤\Gamma^{h}\neq\Gamma^{h^{\prime}}. We do not require that the awareness level determines the game a player considers possible. This extra flexibility allows us to model a situation where, for example, players 2 and 3, who have the same awareness level and agree on the awareness level of player 1, have different beliefs about the game player 1 considers possible.222If the beliefs of players 2 and 3 regarding 1 are compatible with a common prior, then we can view players 2 and 3 as considering different information sets in the same game possible. However, if their beliefs are not compatible with a common prior, for example, if player 2 believes that player 1 believes that, in history h‚Ñéh, Œì1subscriptŒì1\Gamma_{1} is the actual game with probability 1, and player 3 believes that, in history h‚Ñéh, player 1 believes that Œì2subscriptŒì2\Gamma_{2} is the actual game with probability 1, where Œì1‚â†Œì2subscriptŒì1subscriptŒì2\Gamma_{1}\neq\Gamma_{2}, then we cannot view players 2 and 3 as considering the same game possible.

A standard extensive game ŒìŒì\Gamma can be identified with the game ({Œìm},Œìm,‚Ñ±)superscriptŒìùëösuperscriptŒìùëö‚Ñ±(\{\Gamma^{m}\},\Gamma^{m},{\cal F}), where (abusing notation slightly) Œìm=(Œì,{Ai:i‚ààN})superscriptŒìùëöŒìconditional-setsubscriptùê¥ùëñùëñùëÅ\Gamma^{m}=(\Gamma,\{{A}_{i}:i\in N\}) and, for all histories h‚Ñéh in an iùëñi-information set IùêºI in ŒìŒì\Gamma, Ai‚Äã(h)=Hsubscriptùê¥ùëñ‚Ñéùêª{A}_{i}(h)=H and ‚Ñ±‚Äã(Œìm,h)=(Œìm,I)‚Ñ±superscriptŒìùëö‚ÑésuperscriptŒìùëöùêº{\cal F}(\Gamma^{m},h)=(\Gamma^{m},I). Thus, all players are aware of all the runs in ŒìŒì\Gamma, and agree with each other and the modeler that the game is ŒìŒì\Gamma. We call this the canonical representation of ŒìŒì\Gamma as a game with awareness.

One technical issue: We have assumed that the set ùí¢ùí¢{\cal G} of games in a game Œì‚àósuperscriptŒì\Gamma^{*} with awareness is countable. For our purposes, this is without loss of generality. We are ultimately interested in what happens in the game ŒìmsuperscriptŒìùëö\Gamma^{m}, since this is the game actually being played. However, to analyze that, we need to consider what happens in other games in ùí¢ùí¢{\cal G}. For example, if h‚Ñéh is a history in ŒìmsuperscriptŒìùëö\Gamma^{m} where iùëñi moves, we need to understand what happens in the game ŒìhsuperscriptŒì‚Ñé\Gamma^{h} such that ‚Ñ±‚Äã(Œìm,h)=(Œìh,‚ãÖ)‚Ñ±superscriptŒìùëö‚ÑésuperscriptŒì‚Ñé‚ãÖ{\cal F}(\Gamma^{m},h)=(\Gamma^{h},\cdot), since ŒìhsuperscriptŒì‚Ñé\Gamma^{h} is the game that iùëñi thinks is being played at history h‚Ñéh in ŒìmsuperscriptŒìùëö\Gamma^{m}. It is not hard to see that the set of games we need to consider is the least set ùí¢‚Ä≤superscriptùí¢‚Ä≤{\cal G}^{\prime} such that Œìm‚ààùí¢‚Ä≤superscriptŒìùëösuperscriptùí¢‚Ä≤\Gamma^{m}\in{\cal G}^{\prime} and, for every Œì‚Ä≤‚ààùí¢superscriptŒì‚Ä≤ùí¢\Gamma^{\prime}\in{\cal G} and history h‚Ñéh in Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime} such that ‚Ñ±‚Äã(Œì‚Ä≤,h)=(Œì‚Ä≤‚Ä≤,‚ãÖ)‚Ñ±superscriptŒì‚Ä≤‚ÑésuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚ãÖ{\cal F}(\Gamma^{\prime},h)=(\Gamma^{\prime\prime},\cdot), Œì‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚ààùí¢‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤‚Ä≤superscriptùí¢‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime\prime}\in{\cal G}^{\prime}. ùí¢‚Ä≤superscriptùí¢‚Ä≤{\cal G}^{\prime} is guaranteed to be countable, even if ùí¢ùí¢{\cal G} is not.

3 Local strategies and generalized Nash equilibrium

3.1 Local Strategies

In this section, we generalize the notion of Nash equilibrium to games with awareness. To do that, we must first define what a strategy is in a game with awareness. Recall that in a standard game, a strategy for player iùëñi is a function from iùëñi-information sets to a move or to a distribution over moves, depending on whether we are considering pure (i.e., deterministic) strategies or behavioral (i.e., randomized) strategies. The intuition is that player iùëñi‚Äôs actions depend on what iùëñi knows; the strategy can be viewed as a universal plan, describing what iùëñi will do in every possible situation that can arise. This makes sense only because iùëñi is presumed to know the game tree, and thus to know in advance all the situations that can arise.

In games with awareness, this intuition no longer makes sense. For example, player iùëñi cannot plan in advance for what will happen if he becomes aware of something he is initially unaware of. We must allow iùëñi‚Äôs strategy to change if he becomes aware of more moves. Let ùí¢i={Œì‚Ä≤‚ààùí¢:for some¬†‚ÄãŒì+‚ààùí¢‚Äã¬†and¬†‚Äãh‚Äã¬†in¬†‚ÄãŒì+,P+‚Äã(h)=i‚Äã¬†and¬†‚Äã‚Ñ±‚Äã(Œì+,h)=(Œì‚Ä≤,‚ãÖ)}subscriptùí¢ùëñconditional-setsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤ùí¢formulae-sequencefor some¬†superscriptŒìùí¢¬†and¬†‚Ñé¬†in¬†superscriptŒìsuperscriptùëÉ‚Ñéùëñ¬†and¬†‚Ñ±superscriptŒì‚ÑésuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤‚ãÖ{\cal G}_{i}=\{\Gamma^{\prime}\in{\cal G}:\,\mbox{for some }\Gamma^{+}\in{\cal G}\mbox{ and }h\mbox{ in }\Gamma^{+},\,P^{+}(h)=i\mbox{ and }{\cal F}(\Gamma^{+},h)=(\Gamma^{\prime},\cdot)\}. Intuitively, ùí¢isubscriptùí¢ùëñ{\cal G}_{i} consists of the games that iùëñi views as the real game in some history. Thus, rather than considering a single strategy in a game Œì‚àó=(ùí¢,Œìm,‚Ñ±)superscriptŒìùí¢superscriptŒìùëö‚Ñ±\Gamma^{*}=({\cal G},\Gamma^{m},{\cal F}) with awareness, we consider a collection {œÉi,Œì‚Ä≤:Œì‚Ä≤‚ààùí¢i}conditional-setsubscriptùúéùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤subscriptùí¢ùëñ\{\sigma_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}}:\Gamma^{\prime}\in{\cal G}_{i}\} of what we call local strategies, one for each augmented game in ùí¢isubscriptùí¢ùëñ{\cal G}_{i}. Intuitively, a local strategy œÉi,Œì‚Ä≤subscriptùúéùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤\sigma_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}} for game Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime} is the strategy that iùëñi would use if iùëñi were called upon to play and iùëñi thought that the true game was Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime}. Thus, the domain of œÉi,Œì‚Ä≤subscriptùúéùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤\sigma_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}} consists of pairs (Œì+,h)superscriptŒì‚Ñé(\Gamma^{+},h) such that Œì+‚ààùí¢superscriptŒìùí¢\Gamma^{+}\in{\cal G}, h‚Ñéh is a history in Œì+superscriptŒì\Gamma^{+}, P+‚Äã(h)=isuperscriptùëÉ‚ÑéùëñP^{+}(h)=i, and ‚Ñ±‚Äã(Œì+,h)=(Œì‚Ä≤,I)‚Ñ±superscriptŒì‚ÑésuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤ùêº{\cal F}(\Gamma^{+},h)=(\Gamma^{\prime},I).

Define an equivalence relation ‚àºisubscriptsimilar-toùëñ\sim_{i} on pairs (Œì‚Ä≤,h)superscriptŒì‚Ä≤‚Ñé(\Gamma^{\prime},h) such that Œì‚Ä≤‚ààùí¢superscriptŒì‚Ä≤ùí¢\Gamma^{\prime}\in{\cal G} and h‚Ñéh is a history in Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime} where iùëñi moves such that (Œì1,h1)‚àºi(Œì2,h2)subscriptsimilar-toùëñsubscriptŒì1subscript‚Ñé1subscriptŒì2subscript‚Ñé2(\Gamma_{1},h_{1})\sim_{i}(\Gamma_{2},h_{2}) if ‚Ñ±‚Äã(Œì1,h1)=‚Ñ±‚Äã(Œì2,h2)‚Ñ±subscriptŒì1subscript‚Ñé1‚Ñ±subscriptŒì2subscript‚Ñé2{\cal F}(\Gamma_{1},h_{1})={\cal F}(\Gamma_{2},h_{2}). We can think of ‚àºisubscriptsimilar-toùëñ\sim_{i} as defining a generalized information partition in Œì‚àósuperscriptŒì\Gamma^{*}. It is easy to check that a ‚àºisubscriptsimilar-toùëñ\sim_{i} equivalence class consists of a union of iùëñi-information sets in individual games in ùí¢ùí¢{\cal G}. Moreover, if some element of a ‚àºisubscriptsimilar-toùëñ\sim_{i} equivalence class is in the domain of œÉi,Œì‚Ä≤subscriptùúéùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤\sigma_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}}, then so is the whole equivalence class. At all pairs (Œì‚Ä≤,h‚Ä≤)superscriptŒì‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤(\Gamma^{\prime},h^{\prime}) in a ‚àºisubscriptsimilar-toùëñ\sim_{i} equivalence class, if ‚Ñ±‚Äã(Œì‚Ä≤,h‚Ä≤)=(Œìh‚Ä≤,I)‚Ñ±superscriptŒì‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤superscriptŒìsuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤ùêº{\cal F}(\Gamma^{\prime},h^{\prime})=(\Gamma^{h^{\prime}},I), player iùëñi thinks he is actually playing in the information set IùêºI of Œìh‚Ä≤superscriptŒìsuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤\Gamma^{h^{\prime}}. Thus, we require that œÉi,Œì‚Ä≤‚Äã(Œì1,h1)=œÉi,Œì‚Ä≤‚Äã(Œì2,h2)subscriptùúéùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤subscriptŒì1subscript‚Ñé1subscriptùúéùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤subscriptŒì2subscript‚Ñé2\sigma_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}}(\Gamma_{1},h_{1})=\sigma_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}}(\Gamma_{2},h_{2}) if (Œì1,h1)subscriptŒì1subscript‚Ñé1(\Gamma_{1},h_{1}) and (Œì2,h2)subscriptŒì2subscript‚Ñé2(\Gamma_{2},h_{2}) are both in the domain of œÉi,Œì‚Ä≤subscriptùúéùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤\sigma_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}} and (Œì1,h1)‚àºi(Œì2,h2)subscriptsimilar-toùëñsubscriptŒì1subscript‚Ñé1subscriptŒì2subscript‚Ñé2(\Gamma_{1},h_{1})\sim_{i}(\Gamma_{2},h_{2}).

The following definition summarizes this discussion.

Definition 3.1

Given a game with awareness Œì‚àó=(ùí¢,\Gamma^{*}=({\cal G}, Œìm,‚Ñ±)\Gamma^{m},{\cal F}), a local strategy œÉi,Œì‚Ä≤subscriptùúéùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤\sigma_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}} for agent iùëñi is a function mapping pairs (Œì+,h)superscriptŒì‚Ñé(\Gamma^{+},h) such that h‚Ñéh is a history where iùëñi moves in Œì+superscriptŒì\Gamma^{+} and ‚Ñ±‚Äã(Œì+,h)=(Œì‚Ä≤,I)‚Ñ±superscriptŒì‚ÑésuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤ùêº{\cal F}(\Gamma^{+},h)=(\Gamma^{\prime},I) to a probability distribution over Mh‚Ä≤‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤M^{\prime}_{h^{\prime}}, the moves available at a history h‚Ä≤‚ààIsuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤ùêºh^{\prime}\in I, such that œÉi,Œì‚Ä≤‚Äã(Œì1,h1)=œÉi,Œì‚Ä≤‚Äã(Œì2,h2)subscriptùúéùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤subscriptŒì1subscript‚Ñé1subscriptùúéùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤subscriptŒì2subscript‚Ñé2\sigma_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}}(\Gamma_{1},h_{1})=\sigma_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}}(\Gamma_{2},h_{2}) if (Œì1,h1)‚àºi(Œì2,h2)subscriptsimilar-toùëñsubscriptŒì1subscript‚Ñé1subscriptŒì2subscript‚Ñé2(\Gamma_{1},h_{1})\sim_{i}(\Gamma_{2},h_{2}).

Note that there may be no relationship between the strategies œÉi,Œì‚Ä≤subscriptùúéùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤\sigma_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}} for different games Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime}. Intuitively, this is because discovering about the possibility of a different move may cause agent iùëñi to totally alter his strategy. We could impose some consistency requirements, but we have not found any that we believe should hold in all games. We believe that all our results would continue to hold in the presence of reasonable additional requirements, although we have not explored the space of such requirements.

3.2 Generalized Nash Equilibrium

We want to define a notion of generalized Nash equilibrium so as to capture the intuition that for every player iùëñi, if iùëñi believes he is playing game Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime}, then his local strategy œÉi,Œì‚Ä≤subscriptùúéùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤\sigma_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}} is a best response to the local strategies of other players in¬†Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime}.

Define a generalized strategy profile of Œì‚àó=(ùí¢,Œìm,‚Ñ±)superscriptŒìùí¢superscriptŒìùëö‚Ñ±\Gamma^{*}=({\cal G},\Gamma^{m},{\cal F}) to be a set of local strategies œÉ‚Üí={œÉi,Œì‚Ä≤:i‚ààN,Œì‚Ä≤‚ààùí¢i}‚Üíùúéconditional-setsubscriptùúéùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤formulae-sequenceùëñùëÅsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤subscriptùí¢ùëñ\vec{\sigma}=\{\sigma_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}}:i\in N,\Gamma^{\prime}\in{\cal G}_{i}\}. Let E‚ÄãUi,Œì‚Ä≤‚Äã(œÉ‚Üí)ùê∏subscriptùëàùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤‚ÜíùúéEU_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}}(\vec{\sigma}) be the expected payoff for iùëñi in the game Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime} given that strategy profile œÉ‚Üí‚Üíùúé\vec{\sigma} is used. Note that the only strategies in œÉ‚Üí‚Üíùúé\vec{\sigma} that are needed to compute E‚ÄãUi,Œì‚Ä≤‚Äã(œÉ‚Üí)ùê∏subscriptùëàùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤‚ÜíùúéEU_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}}(\vec{\sigma}) are the strategies actually used in Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime}; indeed, all that is needed is the restriction of these strategies to information sets that arise in Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime}.

A generalized Nash equilibrium of Œì‚àó=(ùí¢,Œìm,‚Ñ±)superscriptŒìùí¢superscriptŒìùëö‚Ñ±\Gamma^{*}=({\cal G},\Gamma^{m},{\cal F}) is a generalized strategy profile œÉ‚Üí‚Üíùúé\vec{\sigma} such that for all Œì‚Ä≤‚ààùí¢isuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤subscriptùí¢ùëñ\Gamma^{\prime}\in{\cal G}_{i}, the local strategy œÉi,Œì‚Ä≤subscriptùúéùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤\sigma_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}} is a best response to œÉ‚Üí‚àí(i,Œì‚Ä≤)subscript‚ÜíùúéùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤\vec{\sigma}_{-(i,\Gamma^{\prime})}, where œÉ‚Üí‚àí(i,Œì‚Ä≤)subscript‚ÜíùúéùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤\vec{\sigma}_{-(i,\Gamma^{\prime})} is the set of all local strategies in œÉ‚Üí‚Üíùúé\vec{\sigma} except œÉi,Œì‚Ä≤subscriptùúéùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤\sigma_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}}.

Definition 3.2

A generalized strategy profile œÉ‚Üí‚àósuperscript‚Üíùúé\vec{\sigma}^{*} is a generalized Nash equilibrium of a game Œì‚àó=(ùí¢,Œìm,‚Ñ±)superscriptŒìùí¢superscriptŒìùëö‚Ñ±\Gamma^{*}=({\cal G},\Gamma^{m},{\cal F}) with awareness if, for every player iùëñi, game Œì‚Ä≤‚ààùí¢isuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤subscriptùí¢ùëñ\Gamma^{\prime}\in{\cal G}_{i}, and local strategy œÉùúé\sigma for iùëñi in Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime},

E‚ÄãUi,Œì‚Ä≤‚Äã(œÉ‚Üí‚àó)‚â•E‚ÄãUi,Œì‚Ä≤‚Äã((œÉ‚Üí‚àí(i,Œì‚Ä≤)‚àó,œÉ)).ùê∏subscriptùëàùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤superscript‚Üíùúéùê∏subscriptùëàùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscript‚ÜíùúéùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤ùúéEU_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}}(\vec{\sigma}^{*})\geq EU_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}}((\vec{\sigma}^{*}_{-(i,\Gamma^{\prime})},\sigma)).

The standard definition of Nash equilibrium would say that œÉ‚Üí‚Üíùúé\vec{\sigma} is a Nash equilibrium if œÉisubscriptùúéùëñ\sigma_{i} is a best response to œÉ‚Üí‚àíisubscript‚Üíùúéùëñ\vec{\sigma}_{-i}. This definition implicitly assumes that player iùëñi can choose a whole strategy. This is inappropriate in our setting. An agent cannot anticipate that he will become aware of more moves. Essentially, if Œì1‚â†Œì2subscriptŒì1subscriptŒì2\Gamma_{1}\neq\Gamma_{2}, we are treating player iùëñi who considers the true game to be Œì1subscriptŒì1\Gamma_{1} to be a different agent from the version of player iùëñi who considers Œì2subscriptŒì2\Gamma_{2} to be the true game. To understand why this is appropriate, suppose that player iùëñi considers Œì1subscriptŒì1\Gamma_{1} to be the true game, and then learns about more moves, and so considers Œì2subscriptŒì2\Gamma_{2} to be the true game. At that point, it is too late for player iùëñi to change the strategy he was playing when he thought the game was Œì1subscriptŒì1\Gamma_{1}. He should just try to play optimally for what he now considers the true game. Moreover, while player iùëñi thinks that the game Œì1subscriptŒì1\Gamma_{1} is the true game, he never considers it possible that he will ever be playing a different game, so that he cannot ‚Äúprepare himself‚Äù for a change in his subjective view of the game.333 In games with awareness of unawareness, an agent may consider it possible that he will become aware of more information. But this too is incorporated in his view of the game, so he can still do no better than playing optimally in his current view of the game. These considerations suggest that our notion of Nash equilibrium is appropriate.

It is easy to see that œÉ‚Üí‚Üíùúé\vec{\sigma} is a Nash equilibrium of a standard game iff œÉ‚Üí‚Üíùúé\vec{\sigma} is a (generalized) Nash equilibrium of the canonical representation of ŒìŒì\Gamma as a game with awareness. Thus, our definition of generalized Nash equilibrium generalizes the standard definition.

Consider the game with awareness shown in Figures 1 (taking this to be ŒìmsuperscriptŒìùëö\Gamma^{m}), 2, and 3. We have ùí¢A={ŒìA,ŒìB}subscriptùí¢ùê¥superscriptŒìùê¥superscriptŒìùêµ{\cal G}_{A}=\{\Gamma^{A},\Gamma^{B}\} and ùí¢B={Œìm,ŒìB}subscriptùí¢ùêµsuperscriptŒìùëösuperscriptŒìùêµ{\cal G}_{B}=\{\Gamma^{m},\Gamma^{B}\}. Taking ùëëùëúùëö‚Äã(œÉi,Œì‚Ä≤)ùëëùëúùëösubscriptùúéùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤\mathit{dom}(\sigma_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}}) to denote the domain of the strategy œÉi,Œì‚Ä≤subscriptùúéùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤\sigma_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}}, we have

ùëëùëúùëö‚Äã(œÉA,ŒìA)={(Œìm,‚ü®‚ü©),(ŒìA,‚ü®unaware‚ü©),(ŒìA,‚ü®aware‚ü©)},ùëëùëúùëö‚Äã(œÉB,Œìm)={(Œìm,‚ü®acrossA‚ü©),(ŒìA,‚ü®aware, acrossA‚ü©)},ùëëùëúùëö‚Äã(œÉA,ŒìB)={(ŒìB,‚ü®‚ü©)},¬†and¬†ùëëùëúùëö‚Äã(œÉB,ŒìB)={(ŒìA,‚ü®unaware,acrossA‚ü©),(ŒìB,‚ü®acrossA‚ü©)}.ùëëùëúùëösubscriptùúéùê¥superscriptŒìùê¥superscriptŒìùëösuperscriptŒìùê¥delimited-‚ü®‚ü©unawaresuperscriptŒìùê¥delimited-‚ü®‚ü©awareùëëùëúùëösubscriptùúéùêµsuperscriptŒìùëösuperscriptŒìùëödelimited-‚ü®‚ü©subscriptacrossùê¥superscriptŒìùê¥delimited-‚ü®‚ü©subscriptaware, acrossùê¥ùëëùëúùëösubscriptùúéùê¥superscriptŒìùêµsuperscriptŒìùêµ¬†and¬†ùëëùëúùëösubscriptùúéùêµsuperscriptŒìùêµsuperscriptŒìùê¥delimited-‚ü®‚ü©subscriptunaware,acrossùê¥superscriptŒìùêµdelimited-‚ü®‚ü©subscriptacrossùê¥\begin{array}[]{l}\mathit{dom}(\sigma_{A,\Gamma^{A}})=\{(\Gamma^{m},\langle\,\rangle),(\Gamma^{A},\langle\mbox{unaware}\rangle),(\Gamma^{A},\langle\mbox{aware}\rangle)\},\\ \mathit{dom}(\sigma_{B,\Gamma^{m}})=\{(\Gamma^{m},\langle\mbox{across}_{A}\rangle),(\Gamma^{A},\langle\mbox{aware, across}_{A}\rangle)\},\\ \mathit{dom}(\sigma_{A,\Gamma^{B}})=\{(\Gamma^{B},\langle\,\rangle)\},\mbox{ and }\\ \mathit{dom}(\sigma_{B,\Gamma^{B}})=\{(\Gamma^{A},\langle\mbox{unaware,across}_{A}\rangle),(\Gamma^{B},\langle\mbox{across}_{A}\rangle)\}.\end{array}

Each of these domains consists of a single generalized information set. If p<1/2ùëù12p<1/2, then there exists a generalized Nash equilibrium where œÉA,ŒìA=subscriptùúéùê¥superscriptŒìùê¥absent\sigma_{A,\Gamma^{A}}= acrossA, œÉA,ŒìB=subscriptùúéùê¥superscriptŒìùêµabsent\sigma_{A,\Gamma^{B}}= downA, œÉB,Œìm=subscriptùúéùêµsuperscriptŒìùëöabsent\sigma_{B,\Gamma^{m}}= downB, œÉB,ŒìB=subscriptùúéùêµsuperscriptŒìùêµabsent\sigma_{B,\Gamma^{B}}= acrossB. Thus, in the modeler‚Äôs game, Aùê¥A plays acrossA, BùêµB plays downB, and the resulting payoff vector is (2,3)23(2,3). On the other hand, if p>1/2ùëù12p>1/2, then there exists a generalized Nash equilibrium where œÉA,ŒìA=subscriptùúéùê¥superscriptŒìùê¥absent\sigma_{A,\Gamma^{A}}= downA, œÉA,ŒìB=subscriptùúéùê¥superscriptŒìùêµabsent\sigma_{A,\Gamma^{B}}= downA, œÉB,Œìm=subscriptùúéùêµsuperscriptŒìùëöabsent\sigma_{B,\Gamma^{m}}= downB, œÉB,ŒìB=subscriptùúéùêµsuperscriptŒìùêµabsent\sigma_{B,\Gamma^{B}}= acrossB. Thus, in the modeler‚Äôs game, Aùê¥A plays downA, and the payoff vector is (1,1)11(1,1). Intuitively, even though both Aùê¥A and BùêµB are aware of all the moves in the modeler‚Äôs game, Aùê¥A considers it sufficiently likely that BùêµB is not aware of downB, so Aùê¥A plays downA. There exists another generalized Nash equilibrium where œÉA,ŒìA=subscriptùúéùê¥superscriptŒìùê¥absent\sigma_{A,\Gamma^{A}}= downA, œÉA,ŒìB=subscriptùúéùê¥superscriptŒìùêµabsent\sigma_{A,\Gamma^{B}}= downA, œÉB,Œìm=subscriptùúéùêµsuperscriptŒìùëöabsent\sigma_{B,\Gamma^{m}}= acrossB, and œÉB,ŒìB=subscriptùúéùêµsuperscriptŒìùêµabsent\sigma_{B,\Gamma^{B}}= acrossB that holds for any value of pùëùp. Intuitively, Aùê¥A believes BùêµB will play acrossB no matter what he (BùêµB) is aware of, and therefore plays downA; given that Aùê¥A plays downA, BùêµB cannot improve by playing downB even is he is aware of that move.444We did not discuss this latter equilibrium in the preliminary version of this paper.

We now show that every game with awareness has at least one generalized Nash equilibrium. We proceed as follows. Given a game Œì‚àó=(ùí¢,Œìm,‚Ñ±)superscriptŒìùí¢superscriptŒìùëö‚Ñ±\Gamma^{*}=({\cal G},\Gamma^{m},{\cal F}) with awareness, let ŒΩùúà\nu be a probability on ùí¢ùí¢{\cal G} that assigns each game in ùí¢ùí¢{\cal G} positive probability. Theorem 3.1

For all probability measures ŒΩùúà\nu on ùí¢ùí¢{\cal G}

  • (a)

    ŒìŒΩsuperscriptŒìùúà\Gamma^{\nu} is a standard extensive game with perfect recall; and

  • (b)

    if ŒΩùúà\nu gives positive probability to all games in ùí¢ùí¢{\cal G}, then œÉ‚Üí‚Üíùúé\vec{\sigma} is a Nash equilibrium of ŒìŒΩsuperscriptŒìùúà\Gamma^{\nu} iff œÉ‚Üí‚Ä≤superscript‚Üíùúé‚Ä≤\vec{\sigma}^{\prime} is a generalized Nash equilibrium of Œì‚àósuperscriptŒì\Gamma^{*}, where œÉi,Œì‚Ä≤‚Äã(‚ü®Œìh‚ü©‚ãÖh‚Ä≤)=œÉi,Œì‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚Äã(Œìh,h‚Ä≤)subscriptùúéùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤‚ãÖdelimited-‚ü®‚ü©superscriptŒì‚Ñésuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùúé‚Ä≤ùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ñésuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤\sigma_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}}(\langle\Gamma^{h}\rangle\cdot h^{\prime})=\sigma^{\prime}_{i,\Gamma^{\prime}}(\Gamma^{h},h^{\prime}).

Although a Nash equilibrium does not necessarily exist in games with infinitely many players, ŒìŒΩsuperscriptŒìùúà\Gamma^{\nu} has three special properties: (a) each player has only finitely many information sets, and (b) for each player (i,Œì‚Ä≤)ùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤(i,\Gamma^{\prime}), there exists a finite subset N‚Äã(i,Œì‚Ä≤)ùëÅùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤N(i,\Gamma^{\prime}) of NŒΩsuperscriptùëÅùúàN^{\nu} such that (i,Œì)ùëñŒì(i,\Gamma)‚Äôs payoff in ŒìŒΩsuperscriptŒìùúà\Gamma^{\nu} depends only on the strategies of the players in N‚Äã(i,Œì‚Ä≤)ùëÅùëñsuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤N(i,\Gamma^{\prime}), and (c) ŒìŒΩsuperscriptŒìùúà\Gamma^{\nu} is a game with perfect recall. This turns out to be enough to show that ŒìŒΩsuperscriptŒìùúà\Gamma^{\nu} has at least one Nash equilibrium. Thus, we get the following corollary to Theorem¬†3.1.

Corollary 3.1

Every game with awareness has a generalized Nash equilibrium.

4 Modeling Awareness of Unawareness

In this section, we describe how to extend our representation of games with awareness to deal with awareness of unawareness. In an augmented game that represents player iùëñi‚Äôs subjective view of the game, we want to model the fact that iùëñi may be aware of the fact that jùëój can make moves at a history h‚Ñéh that iùëñi is not aware of. We do this by allowing jùëój to make a ‚Äúvirtual move‚Äù at history h‚Ñéh. Histories that contain virtual moves are called virtual histories. These virtual histories do not necessarily correspond to a history in the underlying game ŒìŒì\Gamma (i.e., iùëñi may falsely believe that jùëój can make a move at h‚Ñéh that he is unaware of), and even if a virtual history does correspond to a history in ŒìŒì\Gamma, the subgame that follows that virtual history may bear no relationship to the actual subgame that follows the corresponding history in the underlying game ŒìŒì\Gamma. Intuitively, the virtual histories describe agent iùëñi‚Äôs (possibly incomplete and possibly incorrect) view of what would happen in the game if some move she is unaware of is made by agent jùëój. Player jùëój may have several virtual moves available at history h‚Ñéh, and may make virtual moves at a number of histories in the augmented game.555In the preliminary version of the paper, we assumed that all virtual moves were terminal moves. This is appropriate if iùëñi has no idea at all of what will happen in the game after a virtual move is made. The greater generality we allow here is useful to model situations where player iùëñi has some partial understanding of the game. For example, iùëñi may know that he can move left after jùëój‚Äôs virtual move, no matter what that virtual move is. Note that agent iùëñi‚Äôs subjective game may include virtual moves for iùëñi himself; iùëñi may believe that he will become aware of more moves (and may take active steps to try and learn about these moves).

To handle awareness of unawareness, we consider a generalization of the notion of augmented game. We continue to refer to the generalized notion as an augmented game, using ‚Äúaugmented game without awareness of unawareness‚Äù to refer to the special case we have focused on up to now. Formally, Œì+=(N+,M+,H+,P+,fc+,{‚Ñêi+:i‚ààN+},{ui+:i‚ààN+},{Ai+:i‚ààN+})superscriptŒìsuperscriptùëÅsuperscriptùëÄsuperscriptùêªsuperscriptùëÉsuperscriptsubscriptùëìùëêconditional-setsuperscriptsubscript‚ÑêùëñùëñsuperscriptùëÅconditional-setsuperscriptsubscriptùë¢ùëñùëñsuperscriptùëÅconditional-setsuperscriptsubscriptùê¥ùëñùëñsuperscriptùëÅ\Gamma^{+}=(N^{+},M^{+},H^{+},P^{+},f_{c}^{+},\{{\cal I}_{i}^{+}:i\in N^{+}\},\{u_{i}^{+}:i\in N^{+}\},\{{A}_{i}^{+}:i\in N^{+}\}) is an augmented game based on the (standard) finite extensive game Œì=(N,M,H,P,fc,{‚Ñêi:i‚ààN},{ui:i‚ààN})ŒìùëÅùëÄùêªùëÉsubscriptùëìùëêconditional-setsubscript‚ÑêùëñùëñùëÅconditional-setsubscriptùë¢ùëñùëñùëÅ\Gamma=(N,M,H,P,f_{c},\{{\cal I}_{i}:i\in N\},\{u_{i}:i\in N\}) if it satisfies conditions A1‚ÄìA3, A6‚ÄìA10 and A12 of augmented games, and variants of A4, A5, and A8. 666We could also relax A3 to allow some ‚Äúvirtual players‚Äù. We do not do that here for ease of exposition. Before stating these variants we need to define formally the set of virtual histories of Œì+superscriptŒì\Gamma^{+}.     if h‚ãÖ‚ü®m‚ü©‚ààH+‚ãÖ‚Ñédelimited-‚ü®‚ü©ùëösuperscriptùêªh\cdot\langle m\rangle\in H^{+} and h‚ààV+‚Ñésuperscriptùëâh\in V^{+}, then h‚ãÖ‚ü®m‚ü©‚ààV+‚ãÖ‚Ñédelimited-‚ü®‚ü©ùëösuperscriptùëâh\cdot\langle m\rangle\in V^{+};

A game with awareness of unawareness based on ŒìŒì\Gamma is defined as a tuple Œì‚àó=(ùí¢,Œìm,‚Ñ±)superscriptŒìùí¢superscriptŒìùëö‚Ñ±\Gamma^{*}=({\cal G},\Gamma^{m},{\cal F}) just as before.
