    If h‚Ä≤‚ààIsuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤ùêºh^{\prime}\in I and h,h‚Ä≤‚àâVh‚Ñésuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤superscriptùëâ‚Ñéh,h^{\prime}\notin V^{h}, then h¬Ø¬Ø‚Ñé\overline{h} and h¬Ø‚Ä≤superscript¬Ø‚Ñé‚Ä≤\overline{h}^{\prime} are in the same information set in ŒìŒì\Gamma.

C1‚Ä≤ and C6‚Ä≤ have been weakened so that these restrictions only apply to non-virtual histories of ŒìhsuperscriptŒì‚Ñé\Gamma^{h}. Part (a) of C2‚Ä≤ is the same as the first part of C2; part (b) implies that the set of moves available to player jùëój at a non-virtual history h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime} is the set of moves that player iùëñi is aware of that are available to jùëój at h¬Ø‚Ä≤superscript¬Ø‚Ñé‚Ä≤\overline{h}^{\prime} in the underlying game together with some virtual moves. It is not hard to check that in games without awareness of unawareness, part (c) follows from A4, C1, and C2, so it does not need to be explicitly stated in C2. However, now that A4 has been weakened to A4‚Ä≤, we must mention it explicitly.

Note that ŒìmsuperscriptŒìùëö\Gamma^{m} is an augmented game with no awareness of unawareness; there are no virtual moves, since the modeler is indeed aware of all possible moves (and knows it). We can now define local strategies, generalized strategy profiles, and generalized Nash equilibrium just as we did for games with awareness. The same technique as that used to show Corollary¬†3.1 can be used to prove the following.

Theorem 4.1

Every game with awareness of unawareness has a generalized Nash equilibrium.

5 Modeling Lack of Common Knowledge

Game theorists have long searched for good approaches to modeling games where there is no common knowledge among players regarding the game being played. Our approach is flexible enough to handle such lack of common knowledge. In this section, we discuss the changes needed to handle lack of common knowledge. We remark that what we do here makes perfect sense even in games where there is full awareness.

We can modify our model to accommodate four different aspects of lack of common knowledge.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Lack of common knowledge regarding who moves. We assumed that every player understands who moves in each history he is aware of. Although we still need to require that every player knows when it is his turn to move, we can handle the case where a player has false beliefs about who moves after a history that is not in one of his information sets. For example, we are interested in modeling the case where player iùëñi may be confused after some history h‚Ñéh as to whether player jùëój or player kùëòk moves, but in both cases iùëñi still believes that the same moves are available. That is, player iùëñi knows what could happen next, but he does not know who is going to do it. (Later we model uncertainty not only regarding who moves but also regarding what the move is.)

    To explain the necessary modifications, we need one more definition. Let ùí¢m,isubscriptùí¢ùëöùëñ{\cal G}_{m,i} be the smallest subset of ùí¢ùí¢{\cal G} such that if either Œì+=ŒìmsuperscriptŒìsuperscriptŒìùëö\Gamma^{+}=\Gamma^{m} or Œì+‚ààùí¢m,isuperscriptŒìsubscriptùí¢ùëöùëñ\Gamma^{+}\in{\cal G}_{m,i}, h‚ààH+‚Ñésuperscriptùêªh\in H^{+}, P+‚Äã(h)=isuperscriptùëÉ‚ÑéùëñP^{+}(h)=i, and ‚Ñ±‚Äã(Œì+,h)=(Œì‚Ä≤,‚ãÖ)‚Ñ±superscriptŒì‚ÑésuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤‚ãÖ{\cal F}(\Gamma^{+},h)=(\Gamma^{\prime},\cdot), then Œì‚Ä≤‚ààùí¢m,isuperscriptŒì‚Ä≤subscriptùí¢ùëöùëñ\Gamma^{\prime}\in{\cal G}_{m,i}. Intuitively, ùí¢m,isubscriptùí¢ùëöùëñ{\cal G}_{m,i} consists of all games player iùëñi considers possible, or considers possible that he considers possible, and so on, at some history of the modeler‚Äôs game.

    We can model lack of common knowledge about who moves by replacing A4 by

    • A4‚Ä≤‚Ä≤.

      If P+‚Äã(h)=i‚ààN+superscriptùëÉ‚ÑéùëñsuperscriptùëÅP^{+}(h)=i\in N^{+}, then Mh+‚äÜMh¬ØsubscriptsuperscriptùëÄ‚ÑésubscriptùëÄ¬Ø‚ÑéM^{+}_{h}\subseteq M_{\overline{h}}.

    Thus, we no longer require that the player who moves at history h‚Ñéh is necessarily the one who moves at h¬Ø¬Ø‚Ñé\overline{h}. However, we do make this requirement for the modeler‚Äôs game, since the modeler is assumed to understand the underlying game. Thus, we must add a requirement M4 for the modeler‚Äôs game that is identical to A4 except that we replace Œì+superscriptŒì\Gamma^{+} by ŒìmsuperscriptŒìùëö\Gamma^{m}.

    Player iùëñi must also understand that he moves at a history h‚Ñéh iff he moves at h¬Ø¬Ø‚Ñé\overline{h} for games in ùí¢m,isubscriptùí¢ùëöùëñ{\cal G}_{m,i}.

    • C11.

      If Œì+‚ààùí¢superscriptŒìùí¢\Gamma^{+}\in{\cal G}, h‚ààH+‚Ñésuperscriptùêªh\in H^{+}, P+‚Äã(h)=isuperscriptùëÉ‚ÑéùëñP^{+}(h)=i, Ai+‚Äã(h)=asuperscriptsubscriptùê¥ùëñ‚Ñéùëé{A}_{i}^{+}(h)=a, ‚Ñ±‚Äã(Œì+,h)=(Œìh,I)‚Ñ±superscriptŒì‚ÑésuperscriptŒì‚Ñéùêº{\cal F}(\Gamma^{+},h)=(\Gamma^{h},I), and h‚Ä≤‚ààHhsuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤superscriptùêª‚Ñéh^{\prime}\in H^{h}, then if Œìh‚ààùí¢m,isuperscriptŒì‚Ñésubscriptùí¢ùëöùëñ\Gamma^{h}\in{\cal G}_{m,i} and Ph‚Äã(h‚Ä≤)=isuperscriptùëÉ‚Ñésuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤ùëñP^{h}(h^{\prime})=i, then P‚Äã(h¬Ø‚Ä≤)=iùëÉsuperscript¬Ø‚Ñé‚Ä≤ùëñP(\overline{h}^{\prime})=i. Conversely, if P‚Äã(h¬Ø‚Ä≤)=iùëÉsuperscript¬Ø‚Ñé‚Ä≤ùëñP(\overline{h}^{\prime})=i, then there exists a prefix or suffix h‚Ä≤‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤‚Ä≤h^{\prime\prime} of h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime} such that h¬Ø‚Ä≤‚Ä≤=h¬Ø‚Ä≤superscript¬Ø‚Ñé‚Ä≤‚Ä≤superscript¬Ø‚Ñé‚Ä≤\overline{h}^{\prime\prime}=\overline{h}^{\prime} and Ph‚Äã(h‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)=isuperscriptùëÉ‚Ñésuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ùëñP^{h}(h^{\prime\prime})=i.

    We also need to make modifications to A5. Since we want to allow a player to have false beliefs about when nature moves, we replace A5 with

    • A5‚Ä≤‚Ä≤.

      If P+‚Äã(h)=csuperscriptùëÉ‚ÑéùëêP^{+}(h)=c, then either Mh+‚äÜMh¬ØsubscriptsuperscriptùëÄ‚ÑésubscriptùëÄ¬Ø‚ÑéM^{+}_{h}\subseteq M_{\overline{h}}, or Mh+‚à©M=‚àÖsubscriptsuperscriptùëÄ‚ÑéùëÄM^{+}_{h}\cap M=\emptyset.

    As before, the moves in Mh+subscriptsuperscriptùëÄ‚ÑéM^{+}_{h} in the case where Mh+‚à©M=‚àÖsubscriptsuperscriptùëÄ‚ÑéùëÄM^{+}_{h}\cap M=\emptyset intuitively capture uncertainty regarding a player‚Äôs awareness level. But now it may be the case that a player iùëñi falsely believes that nature moves after history h¬Ø¬Ø‚Ñé\overline{h} in the underlying game. Just as with A4, we must add a condition M5 to the modeler‚Äôs game that is identical to A5, except that Œì+superscriptŒì\Gamma^{+} is replaced by ŒìmsuperscriptŒìùëö\Gamma^{m}.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Lack of common knowledge about the information sets. We assumed that every player understand the signals every other player receives in every history he is aware of. We can weaken this assumption by allowing a player to have false beliefs about the signals received by other players, or equivalently, by allowing a player to have false beliefs about the information sets of other players.

    We can model lack of common knowledge about the information sets by removing conditions A8‚ÄìA10. Again, because we assume that the modeler understands the information sets, we would add analogues of A8‚ÄìA10 to the conditions on the modeler‚Äôs game (replacing Œì+superscriptŒì\Gamma^{+} by ŒìmsuperscriptŒìùëö\Gamma^{m}, of course). Similarly, we would require analogues of A8 and A9 to hold in the ‚ÄúC-list‚Äù of conditions for games Œìh‚ààùí¢m,isuperscriptŒì‚Ñésubscriptùí¢ùëöùëñ\Gamma^{h}\in{\cal G}_{m,i}, and we weaken C6 so that it also holds only for Œìh‚ààùí¢m,isuperscriptŒì‚Ñésubscriptùí¢ùëöùëñ\Gamma^{h}\in{\cal G}_{m,i}. We must also add an analogue of A10 to the ‚ÄúC-list‚Äù for games Œìh‚ààùí¢m,isuperscriptŒì‚Ñésubscriptùí¢ùëöùëñ\Gamma^{h}\in{\cal G}_{m,i} for histories h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime} and h‚Ä≤‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤‚Ä≤h^{\prime\prime} in an iùëñi-information set.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Lack of common knowledge about payoffs. We assumed that payoffs depended only on moves of the underlying game and that they were common knowledge among players. By dropping condition A12, we remove both of these assumptions. If we want to require that payoffs depend only on the underlying game, but still want to allow players to have false beliefs about the utilities, we would add an analogue of A12 in the modeler‚Äôs game and use the following weakening of A12:

    • A12‚Ä≤.

      If Œì+‚ààùí¢superscriptŒìùí¢\Gamma^{+}\in{\cal G}, z,z‚Ä≤‚ààZ+ùëßsuperscriptùëß‚Ä≤superscriptùëçz,z^{\prime}\in Z^{+}, and z¬Ø=z¬Ø‚Ä≤¬Øùëßsuperscript¬Øùëß‚Ä≤\overline{z}=\overline{z}^{\prime}, then for all i‚ààN+ùëñsuperscriptùëÅi\in N^{+}, ui+‚Äã(z)=ui+‚Äã(z‚Ä≤)superscriptsubscriptùë¢ùëñùëßsuperscriptsubscriptùë¢ùëñsuperscriptùëß‚Ä≤u_{i}^{+}(z)=u_{i}^{+}(z^{\prime}).

    Although the player jùëój whose view of the game is Œì+superscriptŒì\Gamma^{+} may have false beliefs about the payoffs, player jùëój knows that the payoffs depend only on the moves made in the underlying game. A12‚Ä≤ captures that intuition.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Lack of common knowledge of the underlying game. We assumed players have common knowledge about the structure of the underlying game. Our framework can model a situation where each player has a completely different conception of what game is actually being played, which may have very little relationship to the actual underlying game (although we still assume that the modeler‚Äôs game corresponds to the actual game). The key idea is to drop the assumption that all augmented games are based on the same game ŒìŒì\Gamma.

    To formalize this intuition, we modify A2 so that the Ai+superscriptsubscriptùê¥ùëñ{A}_{i}^{+} function does not necessarily map histories of an augmented game to histories of the same game ŒìŒì\Gamma. Rather, A+‚Äã(h)superscriptùê¥‚Ñé{A}^{+}(h) is the set of histories of some game Œì‚Äã(h)Œì‚Ñé\Gamma(h) that, intuitively, iùëñi considers to be the true underlying game. Thus, if h‚Ñéh and h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime} are two histories in Œì+superscriptŒì\Gamma^{+}, then Ai+‚Äã(h)superscriptsubscriptùê¥ùëñ‚Ñé{A}_{i}^{+}(h) and Ai+‚Äã(h‚Ä≤)superscriptsubscriptùê¥ùëñsuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤{A}_{i}^{+}(h^{\prime}) may be histories in two completely different games. Since Œì‚Äã(h)Œì‚Ñé\Gamma(h) is viewed as iùëñi‚Äôs subjective view of the true underlying game, we assume that he understands it perfectly. Thus, we retain A1, A6 and A8‚ÄìA12 and replace conditions A3‚ÄìA5 by M1‚ÄìM3 (where the set of players is the set of players in Œì‚Äã(h)Œì‚Ñé\Gamma(h) and the projection function maps a history h‚Ñéh to a history h¬Ø¬Ø‚Ñé\overline{h} in Œì‚Äã(h)Œì‚Ñé\Gamma(h)). With regard to A7, note that, even if a player intuitively has perfect recall, he may realize in the future that he does not consider possible a history he considered possible in the past.

    In the definition of games with awareness, we allow ùí¢ùí¢{\cal G} to contain augmented games based on standard games different from the game on which ŒìmsuperscriptŒìùëö\Gamma^{m}, the modeler‚Äôs game, is based. We continue to require conditions C1, C3‚ÄìC5, C7‚ÄìC9, and C11, but we weaken C2. In C2 we required that a player iùëñi cannot consider possible a game ŒìhsuperscriptŒì‚Ñé\Gamma^{h} where one of the players jùëój moving in ŒìhsuperscriptŒì‚Ñé\Gamma^{h} is aware of more runs than iùëñi is. In this setting, we allow iùëñi to consider possible a game ŒìhsuperscriptŒì‚Ñé\Gamma^{h} where one of the players jùëój moving in ŒìhsuperscriptŒì‚Ñé\Gamma^{h} believes (falsely, from iùëñi‚Äôs point of view) that some runs are possible that iùëñi does not consider possible. However, we require that the set of moves that iùëñi believes that jùëój believes are available to him while moving at history h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime} in ŒìhsuperscriptŒì‚Ñé\Gamma^{h} is a subset of the moves iùëñi believes are available to jùëój while moving at h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime}. We thus replace C2 by the following condition C2‚Ä≤‚Ä≤, which is the analogue of parts (b) and (c) of C2‚Ä≤.

    • C2‚Ä≤‚Ä≤.

      If h‚Ä≤‚ààHhsuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤superscriptùêª‚Ñéh^{\prime}\in H^{h}, Ph‚Äã(h‚Ä≤)=jsuperscriptùëÉ‚Ñésuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤ùëóP^{h}(h^{\prime})=j, and ‚Ñ±‚Äã(Œìh,h‚Ä≤)=(Œì‚Ä≤,I‚Ä≤)‚Ñ±superscriptŒì‚Ñésuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤superscriptùêº‚Ä≤{\cal F}(\Gamma^{h},h^{\prime})=(\Gamma^{\prime},I^{\prime}), then for all h‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚ààI‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤‚Ä≤superscriptùêº‚Ä≤h^{\prime\prime}\in I^{\prime}, Mh‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚äÜMh‚Ä≤hsubscriptsuperscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤‚Ä≤subscriptsuperscriptùëÄ‚Ñésuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤M^{\prime}_{h^{\prime\prime}}\subseteq M^{h}_{h^{\prime}}, and Mh¬Ø‚Ä≤‚à©{m:h¬Ø‚Ä≤‚ãÖ‚ü®m‚ü©‚ààa}=Mh‚Ä≤hsubscriptùëÄsuperscript¬Ø‚Ñé‚Ä≤conditional-setùëö‚ãÖsuperscript¬Ø‚Ñé‚Ä≤delimited-‚ü®‚ü©ùëöùëésubscriptsuperscriptùëÄ‚Ñésuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤M_{\overline{h}^{\prime}}\cap\{m:\overline{h}^{\prime}\cdot\langle m\rangle\in a\}=M^{h}_{h^{\prime}}.

    Since we allow players to have false beliefs about information sets, we drop conditions C6 and C10. However, since we have dropped A7 and weakened C2, we now need the following condition, which requires that if a player considers possible a set of histories of the underlying game, then he cannot believe that in the future he will consider possible a different set of histories.777Note that this does not rule out a situation where a player iùëñi realizes at history h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime} that his view of the game will change at a future history h‚Ä≤‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤‚Ä≤h^{\prime\prime} when he receives some additional information. If this is the case, then this should already be described in the set of histories that iùëñi considers possible at h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime}.

    • C12.

      If h‚Ä≤‚ààIsuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤ùêºh^{\prime}\in I, h‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚ààHhsuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤‚Ä≤superscriptùêª‚Ñéh^{\prime\prime}\in H^{h}, Ph‚Äã(h‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)=isuperscriptùëÉ‚Ñésuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ùëñP^{h}(h^{\prime\prime})=i, and h‚Ä≤‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤‚Ä≤h^{\prime\prime} is a suffix of h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime}, then Aih‚Äã(h‚Ä≤)=Aih‚Äã(h‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)superscriptsubscriptùê¥ùëñ‚Ñésuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤superscriptsubscriptùê¥ùëñ‚Ñésuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤‚Ä≤{A}_{i}^{h}(h^{\prime})={A}_{i}^{h}(h^{\prime\prime}).

    It is easy to see what C12 follows from A7, C2, and C4, which is why we did not list it explicitly earlier.

    This approach of allowing the augmented games in ùí¢ùí¢{\cal G} to be based on different underlying games actually subsumes our earlier approach and allows us to capture lack of common knowledge about who moves, what the information sets are, and what the payoffs are. For example, note that despite the fact that we have replaced A3-5 by M1-3, we can also model games with awareness using this approach by taking the game Œì‚Äã(h)Œì‚Ñé\Gamma(h) to be the game consisting only of the runs of ŒìŒì\Gamma that are in A+‚Äã(h)superscriptùê¥‚Ñé{A}^{+}(h). (Of course, if we do that, we need to reinstate A7 and replace C2‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ with C2.) To capture lack of common knowledge about who moves, we take Œì‚Äã(h)Œì‚Ñé\Gamma(h) to be identical to ŒìŒì\Gamma except that different agents may move at a given information set. Similarly, we can model lack of common knowledge about what the information sets and what the payoffs are by restricting Œì‚Äã(h)Œì‚Ñé\Gamma(h) appropriately.

Despite all the changes to the conditions, the definitions of local strategies and generalized Nash equilibrium, and the theorems and their proofs remain unchanged. Thus, our techniques can deal with highly subjective games as well as awareness.

6 Related Work

There have been a number of models for unawareness in the literature (see, for example, [2, 14, 20, 21, 1]). Halpern [?] and Halpern and R√™go [?] showed that in a precise sense all those models are special cases of Fagin and Halpern‚Äôs [2] approach where they modeled awareness syntactically by introducing a new modal operator for it. Halpern and R√™go [11] extended Fagin and Halpern‚Äôs logic of awareness to deal with knowledge of unawareness. All of these papers focused on logic, and did not analyze the impact of unawareness in a strategic setting.

Feinberg‚Äôs [?, ?] work is most similar work to ours. We discussed the high-level difference between our work and that of Feinberg in the introduction. Here we focus on some of the more detailed differences:

  • ‚Ä¢

    Feinberg does not model games semantically. He encodes all the information in the ‚Ñ±‚Ñ±{\cal F} function syntactically, by describing each player‚Äôs awareness level and iterated nested awareness levels (e.g., what player 111 is aware that player 222 is aware that player 333 is aware of).

  • ‚Ä¢

    In dealing with extensive games, Feinberg¬†[?] assumes that the runs that a player is aware of completely determine what game he believes he is playing. It cannot be the case that there are two distinct ‚Äúidentities‚Äù of a player that have the same awareness level. As we discussed in Section¬†2, this assumption limits the applicability of the model.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Feinberg assumes that if player iùëñi is aware of player jùëój, then iùëñi must be aware of some move of player jùëój. We do not require such a condition since the analogous condition is not typically assumed in standard extensive games. For example, in a standard extensive game, a player may get a payoff even though there is no node where he can move. But it is trivial to add this requirement (as it would be trivial to drop in Feinberg‚Äôs framework), and making it has no impact on the results.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Feinberg¬†[?] defines payoffs for player iùëñi by using what he calls ‚Äúdefault actions‚Äù for players that iùëñi is unaware of. He says that this default action will be context dependent. We do not have such default actions in our setting; the payoff of a player in our framework is independent of the payoff of the players he is unaware of. The assumption of a default action seems somewhat problematic to us; it is not clear what the default move should be in general. Moreover, if two different players are unaware of player jùëój, it is not clear why (or whether) they should assume the same default action.

  • ‚Ä¢

    In dealing with extensive games, Feinberg¬†[?] defines moves of nature by conditioning on the set of moves of nature the player is aware of. In our framework, this would amount to the following requirement:

    1. C13

      If Œì+‚ààùí¢superscriptŒìùí¢\Gamma^{+}\in{\cal G}, h‚ààH+‚Ñésuperscriptùêªh\in H^{+}, P+‚Äã(h)=isuperscriptùëÉ‚ÑéùëñP^{+}(h)=i, Ai+‚Äã(h)=asuperscriptsubscriptùê¥ùëñ‚Ñéùëé{A}_{i}^{+}(h)=a, ‚Ñ±‚Äã(Œì+,h)=(Œìh,I)‚Ñ±superscriptŒì‚ÑésuperscriptŒì‚Ñéùêº{\cal F}(\Gamma^{+},h)=(\Gamma^{h},I), h‚Ä≤‚ààHhsuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤superscriptùêª‚Ñéh^{\prime}\in H^{h}, Ph‚Äã(h‚Ä≤)=csuperscriptùëÉ‚Ñésuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤ùëêP^{h}(h^{\prime})=c, and Mh‚Ä≤h‚à©Mh¬Ø‚Ä≤‚â†‚àÖsubscriptsuperscriptùëÄ‚Ñésuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤subscriptùëÄsuperscript¬Ø‚Ñé‚Ä≤M^{h}_{h^{\prime}}\cap M_{\overline{h}^{\prime}}\neq\emptyset, then fch‚Äã(m‚à£h‚Ä≤)=fc‚Äã(m‚à£h¬Ø‚Ä≤)fc‚Äã(Mh‚Ä≤h‚à£h¬Ø‚Ä≤)subscriptsuperscriptùëì‚Ñéùëêconditionalùëösuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤subscriptùëìùëêconditionalùëösuperscript¬Ø‚Ñé‚Ä≤subscriptùëìùëêconditionalsubscriptsuperscriptùëÄ‚Ñésuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤superscript¬Ø‚Ñé‚Ä≤\mbox{$f^{h}_{c}(m\mid h^{\prime})$}=\frac{f_{c}(m\mid\overline{h}^{\prime})}{f_{c}(M^{h}_{h^{\prime}}\mid\overline{h}^{\prime})} for every m‚ààMh‚Ä≤hùëösubscriptsuperscriptùëÄ‚Ñésuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤m\in M^{h}_{h^{\prime}} and fch‚Äã(m‚à£h‚Ä≤)=0subscriptsuperscriptùëì‚Ñéùëêconditionalùëösuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤0f^{h}_{c}(m\mid h^{\prime})=0 if m‚àâMh‚Ä≤hùëösubscriptsuperscriptùëÄ‚Ñésuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤m\notin M^{h}_{h^{\prime}}.

    As Feinberg did, for that condition to be well defined we require that fc‚Äã(m‚à£h¬Ø)‚â†0subscriptùëìùëêconditionalùëö¬Ø‚Ñé0f_{c}(m\mid\overline{h})\neq 0 for all m‚ààMh¬ØùëösubscriptùëÄ¬Ø‚Ñém\in M_{\overline{h}} and histories h‚Ñéh. As we discussed in Section¬†2, while we believe such a requirement makes sense if nature‚Äôs move is interpreted objectively, it does not make sense in general so we do not assume this in every augmented game.

Sadzik¬†[?] considers a logic of awareness, knowledge, and probability based on that of Heifetz, Meier, and Schipper [?], and uses it to give a definition of Bayesian equilibrium in normal-form games with awareness. Heifetz, Meier and Schipper¬†[?] also consider a generalized state-space model with interactive unawareness and probabilistic beliefs and give a definition of Bayesian equilibrium in normal-form games, without assuming Feinberg‚Äôs restriction. Li [?] has also provided a model of unawareness in extensive games, based on her earlier work on modeling unawareness [18, 19]. Although her representation of a game with unawareness is quite similar to ours, her notion of generalized Nash equilibrium is different from ours. Just as we do, she requires that every player iùëñi make a best response with respect to his beliefs regarding other player‚Äôs strategies in the game ŒìisuperscriptŒìùëñ\Gamma^{i} that iùëñi considers possible. However, unlike us, she requires that these beliefs satisfy a consistency requirement that implies, for example, that if a player iùëñi is aware of the same set of moves for him at both information set I1subscriptùêº1I_{1} in game Œì1subscriptŒì1\Gamma_{1} and information set I2subscriptùêº2I_{2} in Œì2subscriptŒì2\Gamma_{2}, and these information sets correspond to the same information set in the underlying game ŒìŒì\Gamma, then the local strategies œÉi,Œì1subscriptùúéùëñsubscriptŒì1\sigma_{i,\Gamma_{1}} and œÉi,Œì2subscriptùúéùëñsubscriptŒì2\sigma_{i,\Gamma_{2}} must agree at these information sets; that is, œÉi,Œì1‚Äã(I1)=œÉi,Œì2‚Äã(I2)subscriptùúéùëñsubscriptŒì1subscriptùêº1subscriptùúéùëñsubscriptŒì2subscriptùêº2\sigma_{i,\Gamma_{1}}(I_{1})=\sigma_{i,\Gamma_{2}}(I_{2}).

Ozbay [?] proposes a model for games with uncertainty where players may have different awareness levels regarding a move of nature. He assumes that one of the players is fully aware, and can tell the other player about these moves before the second player moves. Although our model can easily capture this setting, what is interesting about Ozbay‚Äôs approach is that the second player‚Äôs beliefs about the probability of these revealed moves of are formed as part of the equilibrium definition. Filiz [?] uses Ozbay‚Äôs model in the context of incomplete contracts in the presence of unforseen contingencies. In this setting, the insurer is assumed to be fully aware of the contingencies, and to decide strategically which contingencies to include in a contract, while the insuree may not be aware of all possible contingencies.

Finally, we remark that our notion of a game with awareness as consisting of the modeler‚Äôs game together with description of which game each agent thinks is the actual game at each history has much in common with the intuition behind Gal and Pfeffer‚Äôs [?] notion of a Network of Influence Diagrams (NID). Formally, NIDs are a graphical language for representing uncertainty over decision-making models. A node in a NID (called a block by Gal and Pfeffer) represents an agent‚Äôs subjective belief about the underlying game and what the strategies used by agents depend on. Each node (game) in a NID is associated with a multiagent influence diagram [15] (MAID), which is a compact representation of a game. A NID has directed edges between nodes labeled by pairs of the form (i,H)ùëñùêª(i,H), where iùëñi is an agent and (in our language) HùêªH is a set of histories. Intuitively, if there an edges from a node (game) ŒìŒì\Gamma to a node Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime} in a NID labeled by a pair (i,H)ùëñùêª(i,H), then HùêªH is a set a set of histories in ŒìŒì\Gamma, there is an agent jùëój that moves at all the histories in HùêªH, and in game ŒìŒì\Gamma, iùëñi believes that jùëój believes that Œì‚Ä≤superscriptŒì‚Ä≤\Gamma^{\prime} is the true game when moving at a history h‚ààH‚Ñéùêªh\in H.

Although Gal and Pfeffer do not try to handle notions of awareness with NIDs, it seems possible to extend them to handle awareness. To do this appropriately, consistency requirements similar to C1‚ÄìC10 will need to be imposed.

7 Conclusion

We have generalized the representation of games to take into account agents who may not be aware of all the moves or all the other agents, but may be aware of their lack of awareness. Moreover, our representation is also flexible enough to deal with subjective games when there is lack of common knowledge about the game, even if awareness is not an issue. We have also shown how to define strategies and Nash equilibrium in such settings. These generalizations greatly increase the applicability of game-theoretic notions in multiagent systems. In large games involving many agents, agents will almost certainly not be aware of all agents and may well not be aware of all the moves that agents can make. Moreover, as we suggested in the introduction, even in well-understood games like chess, by giving awareness a more computational interpretation, we can provide a more realistic model of the game from the agents‚Äô perspective. We remark that although we focus on generalizing extensive-form games, our framework is able to deal with normal-form games as well, since we can view normal-form games as a special case of extensive-form games.

There is clearly much more to be done to understand the role of awareness (and lack of awareness) in multiagent systems. We list some of the many issues here:

  • ‚Ä¢

    We have assumed perfect recall here. But in long games, it seems more reasonable to assume that agents do not have perfect recall. In a long chess game, typical players certainly do not remember all the moves that have been played and the order in which they were played. It is well known that even in single-agent games, considering agents with imperfect recall leads to a number of subtleties (c.f.¬†[7, 24]). We suspect that yet more subtleties will arise when combining imperfect recall with lack of awareness.

  • ‚Ä¢

    In a Nash equilibrium of an extensive-form game, it may be the case that the move made at an information set is not necessarily a best response if that information set is not reached. For example, in the game described in Figure¬†1, even if both players have common knowledge of the game, the profile where Aùê¥A moves down and BùêµB moves across is a Nash equilibrium. Nevertheless moving down is not a best response for BùêµB if BùêµB is actually called upon to play. The only reason that this is a Nash equilibrium is that BùêµB does not in fact play. Sequential equilibrium [16] is a solution concept that is arguably more appropriate for an extensive-form game; it refines Nash equilibrium (in the sense that every sequential equilibrium is a Nash equilibrium) and does not allow solutions such as (downA, acrossB). Our representation of games with awareness (of unawareness) allows for relatively straightforward generalizations of such refinements of Nash equilibrium. However, there are subtleties involved in showing that generalized versions of these refinements always exist. For example, we no longer have a one-to-one correspondence between the generalized sequential equilibria of the game Œì‚àósuperscriptŒì\Gamma^{*} and the sequential equilibria of the corresponding standard game ŒìŒΩsuperscriptŒìùúà\Gamma^{\nu}. Nevertheless, we believe that we should be able to use a more refined construction to show that a generalized sequential equilibrium exists in every game with awareness.

  • ‚Ä¢

    We have analyzed situations where agents may be unaware of some moves in the underlying game, may be aware of their unawareness, and may have completely false beliefs about the underlying game. Of course, there are other cases of interest where additional properties may hold. For example, consider a large geographically-dispersed game where agents interact only with nearby neighbors. In such a game, an agent may be unaware of exactly who is playing the game (although she may realize that there are other agents besides her neighbors, and even realize that the moves made by distant agents may have an indirect effect on her). To model such a situation, we may want to have virtual moves after which the game does not end, and to allow agents to be aware of subsequences of histories in the underlying game. We suspect that a straightforward extension of the ideas in this paper can deal with such situations, but we have not worked out the details.

  • ‚Ä¢

    There has been a great deal of work on computing Nash equilibria. As we have shown, a generalized Nash equilibrium of a game with awareness is a Nash equilibrium of a standard game. However, this standard game can be rather large. Are there efficient computational techniques for computing generalized Nash equilibrium in interesting special cases?

  • ‚Ä¢

    If there is little shared knowledge regarding the underlying game, the set ùí¢ùí¢{\cal G} of augmented games can be quite large, or even infinite. Is it important to consider all the iterated levels of unawareness encoded in ùí¢ùí¢{\cal G}? Halpern and Moses [?] showed that, in analyzing coordinated attack, no finite level of knowledge suffices; common knowledge is needed for coordination. Stopping at any finite level has major implications. Rubinstein [?] considered a variant of the coordinated attack problem with probabilities, and again showed that no finite level suffices (and significant qualitative differences arise if only a finite part of hierarchy of knowledge is considered). On the other hand, Weinstein and Yildiz [?] provide a condition under which the effect of players‚Äô kùëòkth order beliefs is exponentially decreasing in kùëòk. While we strongly suspect that there are games in which higher-order unawareness will be quite relevant, just as with the Weinstein-Yildiz result, there may be conditions under which higher-order awareness becomes less important, and a simpler representation may suffice. Moreover, it may be possible to use NIDs to provide a more compact representation of games of awareness in many cases of interest (just as Bayesian networks provide a compact representation of probability distributions in many cases of interest), leading to more efficient techniques for computing generalized Nash equilibrium.

We hope to explore some of these issues in forthcoming work.

Corollary 3.1: Every game with awareness has a generalized Nash equilibrium.

Proof: For games with perfect recall, there is a natural isomorphism between mixed strategies and behavioral strategies, so a Nash equilibrium in behavior strategies can be viewed as a Nash equilibrium in mixed strategies [22]. Moreover, mixed-strategy Nash equilibria of an extensive-form game are the same as the mixed-strategy Nash equilibria of its normal-form representation. Salonen [?] showed that there exists a Nash equilibrium in mixed strategies in a normal form games with an arbitrary set NùëÅN of players if, for each player iùëñi, the set SisubscriptùëÜùëñS_{i} of pure strategies of player iùëñi is a compact metric space, and the utility functions ui:S‚ÜíI‚ÄãR:subscriptùë¢ùëñ‚ÜíùëÜùêºùëÖu_{i}:S\rightarrow\mbox{$I\!\!R$} are continuous for all i‚ààNùëñùëÅi\in N, where I‚ÄãRùêºùëÖI\!\!R is the set of real numbers and S=Œ†i‚ààN‚ÄãSiùëÜsubscriptŒ†ùëñùëÅsubscriptùëÜùëñS=\Pi_{i\in N}S_{i}, the set of pure strategies, is endowed with the product topology. Since in ŒìŒΩsuperscriptŒìùúà\Gamma^{\nu}, every player has a finite number of pure strategies, SisubscriptùëÜùëñS_{i} is clearly a compact metric space. Moreover, since each player‚Äôs utility depends only on the strategies of a finite number of other players, it is easy to see that ui:S‚ÜíI‚ÄãR:subscriptùë¢ùëñ‚ÜíùëÜùêºùëÖu_{i}:S\rightarrow\mbox{$I\!\!R$} is continuous for each player i‚ààNùëñùëÅi\in N. It follows that there exists a Nash equilibrium of ŒìŒΩsuperscriptŒìùúà\Gamma^{\nu}. Thus, the corollary is immediate from Theorem¬†3.1. ¬†
